totally so just to just to be clear we don't consider Fair Source open source and we want to make sure that uh you
know people understand we're not trying to pawn Fair source off as as an open source license we think it's a separate
and distinct from from open source uh but we do think it has a place in the world so um the reason that we we uh
created the fair Source license is that you know in open source uh you kind of
have this problem and a lot of companies Building open source technology have this problem where you know you want to
build out something great you know a utility that people really rely on and you want to make the source code
publicly available um um because it just feels like the right thing to do as a developer you know as a developer if I'm
curious I want to be able to kind of peek underneath the hood and figure out how something works um nothing's worse
than when you encounter some bug and the thing that you're using is a black box and you have no way of fixing at all or
even understanding what's going wrong uh and so we wanted to make the the source code publicly available but the same
time we wanted to build a sustainable business on top of this because we think that uh this is really problem we're
solving it's going to add a lot of value uh to both technology companies and non-technology companies alike and uh we
think that it's it's fair for um you know people investing time and effort
into building these things to be compensated for the value that they're providing and uh when we looked around
you know the classic kind of way to do this um is is kind of the Dual licensing Mo model where you know you release it
as open source under some like really restrictive license like a GPL or um
agpl and then you have kind of a separate commercial license um but that just didn't seem like a great fit for us
it also I mean if you talk to lawyers in Industry there's actually a lot of concerns around that you know just like
oh you know what if we accidentally you know pull in the GPL part of your codebase and we're not technically
paying for it and it just there's a lot of like fear uncertainty and doubt from
uh the industry side of things things um and we kind of looked around
and said well can we kind of take some things from open source and take some things from uh Clos source and uh and
and make a license that lets us release the uh the source code publicly uh but at the same time you know if a company
like Twitter comes along and wants to use our product uh we can we can charge them a fair price uh for the value that
we're providing to their development team and and so we we kind of looked around uh we we asked a bunch of Open
